abstract: A half a century after losing its status as Brazil’s capital, Rio de Janeiro is becoming an engine of Latin America’s largest economy. The city lured at least two dozen hedge funds in the past decade as well as the nation’s leading oil producers, the 2014 World Cup and the 2016 summer Olympics.
snippet: A half a century after losing its status as Brazil’s capital, Rio de Janeiro is becoming an engine of Latin America’s largest economy. The city lured at least two dozen hedge funds in the past decade as well as the nation’s leading oil producers, ...
lead_paragraph: Christopher Palmer of Gartmore Investment Management needed only a day in Rio de Janeiro to scout for investment opportunities while visiting Brazil six years ago. Now half a week in the city isn’t enough, Bloomberg News reports.

headline.main: Hedge Funds and Other Investors Flock to Rio
